data.title: Allow a stack frame with no source without saying "Unknown source"
data.body:
From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5552, looking at using stack frames with no source as a label for groups of async frames.

Currently when there's no source, they say "Unknown source" on the right. I think that either that label shouldn't be shown, or I should be able to mark a stack frame to have it not shown.

Also these frames are automatically 'deemphasized'. I'm not sure whether I would want that style. It needs to be obvious that these frames are async, and the point of deemphasize is to make a frame easy to ignore. I think that decision should be left up to the debug adapter.

data.title: Command aware terminals

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a proposal to improve VS Code's integration with the terminal output. Currently you may have noticed that the names terminals have in the dropdown may not represent the command currently being run, especially on Windows.

## Problem

On Linux and macOS the behavior is to use the name of the process executable, this does update when new processes are run but unfortunately there is up to a 200ms delay in doing this as we need to poll for it.

On Windows the behavior is to always use the *basename* of the shell process executable (eg. powershell.exe, cmd.exe, etc.), this *does not* change when there is a command run or a shell change.

Due to these limitations we can't reliably tell what process/args are currently being run, and therefore cannot surface this information to integrations.

## Potential Solution

A setting something like this could be introduced:

```js
"terminal.integrated.promptMatchers": {
  "bash": "(bash-\d\.\d)?$\s(.*)",
  "cmd.exe": "..."
}
```

Then depending on the process title we have access to described in the Problem section, we can select the valid item from `promptMatchers`. This could then be used on every line of output to detect when each command starts and finished.

This would enable, among other things, the ability to register link matchers under certain conexts. For example:

```ts
// Linkify \w\.\w in the output of a ls command that will open the file when clicked
// openFile have access to the current working directory from the context
term.registerLinkMatcher(/\w\.\w/, link => openFile(link), 0, /*context*/ 'ls');
```

Given a shell with the default configuration this would allow us to linkify common commands in a relatively 

### Edge Cases

- This wouldn't work for custom shells that are launched within a Windows terminal, for example if cmd.exe is configured and powershell.exe is launched from that terminal, the cmd.exe matcher would be used.
- This would only work for the certain cases when we have the cwd as part of the prompt, if the prompt doesn't contain the cwd would this just be disabled?
- What about multiple line prompts?

### Questions

- Is the setting too complex, especially with the possibility of adding regex indexes?
- This functionality would rely on per-row link matchers upstream as described in https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/538#issuecomment-280146784

## Related items

- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18454 ITerminalInstance support for link detection

**Blocked by**

- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18453 ITerminalInstance.onData should be higher level
- https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/538 xterm.js: Implement web links and custom link matcher registration

data.title: Add concept of "dynamic" (buffer only) settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It appears that in #13328 there was a review of settings that should persist to `settings.json` when changed.

It seems to me that there are some settings should have a default setting that comes from `settings.json`, but should not persist to `settings.json` when changed during editing - a "dynamic" ("buffer only"? need a good term) setting.

For example, `editor.wordWrap` should come from global or workspace `settings.json`, but the `toggleWordWrap` command should change wrapping only for the current buffer (view? editor? session? not sure of correct term) rather than persisting to the `settings.json` file. Examples:

* `editor.wordWrap`
* `editor.wrappingColumn`
* `editor.renderWhitespace`

Reason: I want to leave my default settings as they are but change something only temporarily while editing. I believe the `wordWrap` setting used to behave in this way but this was changed for some reason.

If this is implemented, there should be an API to allow changing these "dynamic" settings also.

data.title: Feature Request: Enable workspace settings to specify required extensions
data.body: We spent 20 minutes with a co-worker yesterday trying to figure out why he couldn't debug an Electron app only to find out he hadn't installed the `Debugger for Chrome` extension.  It would be helpful to teams, if one team member could configure all the required extensions in either `.vscode/settings.json` (or some other file).  At the least, VSCode could then tell someone opening the workspace that they need to install extensions and provide them with the list.  Ideally, VSCode would just install the extensions perhaps with some UI giving the user a chance to cancel (maybe he wandered into the wrong repo).

data.title: Support realtime adjustments of theme colors
data.body:
There are many great themes where the color and contrast don't fit the monitor or lighting conditions of the user.  

As example, the online theme editor allows adjusting overall colors under the 'color adjustments' button.
http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/theme/Monokai

data.title: output window not scrolling to bottom
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

Version 1.10.0-insider
Commit b7dc5cd88bd76d368db5b7c9972c088f533e2bfd
Date 2017-02-15T15:35:32.349Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
OS: ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run a tasks.json command
2. watch the output window

There are other reports about "autoscroll to bottom". My output window is auto scolling, but it doesn't scroll to far enough to show the final line, the final line being very important when my command finishes (I like to `&& echo done` after my build scrips), and the final "done" is below the final visible line, behind the status bar of the window (floating window or fullscreen)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6590223/22991237/8281596a-f370-11e6-85e3-6a0fe1a9d6f4.png)

but if i manually scroll to the end
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6590223/22991263/90f93634-f370-11e6-8af0-188ea65d884d.png)

This happens on every build, even if I put the cursor in the output window and control-home (the cursor is quickly removed from focus, and the window doesn't continue to hold to the end (enough, but partially). If I wait until the task completes and put the cursor in the window and press ^home, i DO see the full text.

Also I understand that I can view the spinning task notification: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6590223/22991427/09a523c2-f371-11e6-949f-504133329efe.png)


But I do prefer to see the final line of my builds
One solution is to add some empty newlines to my makefiles

data.title: The `typescript.check.tscVersion` setting should contain specific version numbers not just true/false
data.body:
Previously I remember seeing the warning about TS version mismatch when my local version was 1.8, but VSCode used already 2.0. In that case this message was useful. However today the mismatch was between 2.1.4 and 2.1.6. Due to my laziness, I decided to click the "Don't check" button.

However, I did not really expect that the check would be disabled completely - but rather for this particular version combination. If VSCode updates to 2.2, I would like to be notified again.

data.title: User snippets don't work inside JSX template
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I created following snippet to quickly generate a component tag in JSX template (in the language JavaScript and JavaScript React )

```json
{
    "FormattedMessage": {
        "prefix": "fmsg",
        "body": [
            "<FormattedMessage id=\"${1:message-id}\"",
            "	tagName=\"${2:span}\"",
            "	defaultMessage=\"${3}\"",
            "	values={{",
            "		${0}",
            "	}}",
            "/>"
        ],
        "description": "react-intl <FormattedMessage>"
    },
}
```

2. In a React .js file, if I place my caret inside other JSX tags and type `fmsg` and tab, it automatically complete as `<fmsg></fmsg>`.
  If I place my caret NOT inside any JSX tags, the prefix `fmsg` completes to full snippet body as expected.

I also tried to add that snippet in language files HTML and XML, but it still doesn't complete in JSX templates.

data.title: Toggle Left Flyout w/ the Keyboard Shortcut from within the Built-In Terminal
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

**VSCode Info:**

```
Version 1.9.1
Commit f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519
Date 2017-02-08T23:44:55.542Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
```

**OS Version:** 
```
Ubuntu 16.04 LTS 64bit
```


**Steps to Reproduce:**

1.Open VS Code
2. Open the console using the keyboard shortcut: CTRL+`
3. With the terminal in focus use the keyboard shortcut: CTRL+b to open and close the left flyout.

**Actual:** Nothing happens, the keyboard shortcuts get ignored.

**Expected:** Toggling of the left flyout.


**Definitions:**

**Left Flyout:** This would include the tree view, search, git, packages, and debug content areas that show/hide up upon pressing CTRL+b with a file in view.

data.title: Add selection to next find match (Ctrl+D) is broken
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10 (1d17b4)
- OS Version: Windows

Background:
Earlier, pressing Ctrl+D would select all occurences of a word, and it was case-insensitive *when Match Case was off*. Now, when I keep pressing Ctrl+D, it keeps selecting those words, but when it encounters first case-sensitively different word, it selects it, and then refuses to select anything at all after it.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type this in your editor:
```
test
testte
Test
testte
test
```
2. Select first `test` and then press Ctrl+D a bunch of times. It stops after selecting `Test`.
![bug2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/760112/22973897/b605dea2-f3a5-11e6-8578-d39510e1e449.gif)


## What it should do:
It shouldn't break after selecting `Test` when Match Case is off.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: windows 10

---

### How to delete blank lines ? 

```
1


2

3
```
to
```
1

2

3
```
&
```
1


2

3
```
to
```
1
2
3
```

---

### How to remove duplicate characters ? 
```
112233445566aabbccddee??//
```
to
```
123456abcde?/
```

---

### How to delete duplicate lines ? 

```
123
123
abc
abc
```
to
```
123
abc
```

data.title: Search test suite fails when running in debug session
data.body:
Related to #20344

1. Launch the `Unit Tests` debug config

```
   2) Search Text: GameOfLife:
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  3) Search Text: GameOfLife (RegExp):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  4) Search Text: GameOfLife (Word Match, Case Sensitive):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  5) Search Text: Helvetica (UTF 16):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  6) Search Text: e:
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  7) Search Text: e (with excludes):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  8) Search Text: e (with includes):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  9) Search Text: e (with includes and exclude):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  10) Search Text: a (capped):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.
  
  11) Search Text: a (no results):
     Error: timeout of 2000ms exceeded. Ensure the done() callback is being called in this test.  
```

There seems to be a problem spawning processes when in this environment. Which brings me to the question: is spawning search processes something that we really should be doing in *unit* tests?

We should independently test the functionality of the `SearchWorkerManager`, `TextSearchWorkerProvider`, etc., on their own. The fact that they run across separate processes on top of an IPC layer shouldn't be reflected on any unit test. That should be done in integration tests only.
